summary: This is an FBI internal request form from the Miami office to the Records Management Division and Special Technologies Office, requesting scanning and automation assistance for telephone records related to the obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez. The document reveals Rodriguez was Jeffrey Epstein's former house manager who attempted to sell an address book believed to contain contact information for additional underage victims.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case opened in October 2009. He came into possession of an address book with names and numbers of potential underage victims of Epstein and attempted to sell it rather than turn it over to authorities.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Subject of a child prostitution case
persons.context: Referred to as the subject of a child prostitution case. Alfredo Rodriguez was his former house manager and butler.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the former house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: FBI opens obstruction case against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opened an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Telephone records collection period
events.description: Telephone records were generated between September 1, 2001 and the present (June 2010) for the investigation.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, was the subject of an FBI obstruction of justice case for attempting to sell an address book containing names and numbers of potential underage victims.
The address book was believed to contain contact information for additional, previously unknown underage victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
The FBI was processing telephone records (target number 714-841-1171) from the address book, believed to belong to Epstein, his associates, or potential victims.
The document is an internal FBI request for technical assistance to scan and automate telephone records for incorporation into the Bureau's Telephone Application (TA) investigative tool.
The records were considered unclassified, but the scanning process involved handling on SECRET-level systems.
